messageBody:
On Fri, 18 Aug 2006 at 06:45:27, Simon Chappell wrote:

> On 8/18/06, kultstatus77 <onlineguy@...> wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> > I'm quite familiar with the purpose of tearDown(), I just fail to see
> > the necessity of it. According to M. Feathers' "Working effectively
> > with legacy code" unit tests don't access databases or communicate via
> > a nreal network connection. I do know that his book's focus is not on
> > JUnit, but I do think that he has a point there. So: without a
> > database and a network connection, when it is really necessary to free
> > up resources with tearDown()? Isn't garbage collecting enough?
>

Here's an example for you.

I run unit tests on custom UI components, some of which require a visible
window. The OS has a limited number of these, so my tests running successfully
depends on timely disposal of these windows. Some tests, in fact, depend on a
certain window configuration, so if a previous test leaves stuff behind, it can
interfere with subsequent tests.

Here's another example:
The JUnit 3 test runners create all test cases before running, and keep
references to them in memory after running. Anything kept as field references
in a test class will not be GC'd until the test runner releases the test class
reference (which is never).
